Title: Love my Fire!
Content: I love my Kindle Fire. So much in fact that I will be purchasing one for my son for Christmas. The way magazines are viewed is a spectacular improvement from my previous Kindle. The battery life based on my style of usage requires daily charging. Not a big deal since I like to sleep at night. So nice that my old Kindle chargers work with the newer model. My 6 y/o nephew was on it and located a video to stream off amazon prime before I could say boo. Not having a smart phone or a lap top, I thought the Kindle Fire was idea for me. I had considered purchasing an iPad.... read the reviews and comparisons... and pre-ordered the Kindle Fire. Most of the reviews I read stated that it was not a true comparison to an iPad, so I didn't expect to get an iPad out of my Amazon box. If you want an iPad, buy an iPad. I wanted a Kindle Fire, and I love it. Is it perfect? NO! It is easy to turn off, but it loads so quickly why complain. You can't adjust the volume from the exterior. I know tapping that screen a couple of times is so difficult, much easier to hit a button a few times. Thanks Amazon for not jacking up the price and using up my storage space on wallpaper and screen savers.

Title: What a beauty :D
Content: I bought this iPad back in June and I must say I was very excited. I've watched to keynote with Steve, but was quite disappointed the lack of features like a camera & 512mb Ram like the iPhone 4, (iPad has only 256mb of Ram). But that didn't stop me from wanting one as a travel companion. As soon as I opened it up, I was just amazed on its beauty, 9.7" display was oh so gorgeous, OS ran smooth like silk. I couldn't wait to download many many apps. I use this thing every single day, take it everywhere I go, for email, internet, reading, Netflix/video, games, notes, music, GPS, the list goes on!! I am pleased with my purchase, and I hope you future iPad owners are as well. :) :DP

Title: Kindle Fire Marware cover is not in stock.
Content: I bought it to use as a reader that is lightweight. I have another Kindle but at night I needed more power. I like it. The browser is just okay. Some videos do not play well. The e-mail program is a little pokey. I guess that I am spoiled by my IPad 2. It was cheap and it very easy to order from Amazon. It is no I Pad.

Title: CAUTION!!! Kindle Fire Glass Shatters!!!!
Content: I was setting my fire on the table last night, I had one side of it on the table and it slipped and landed screen down. I picked it up and the glass had shattered. There were little shards of glass everywhere. I am so glad my 7 year old didn't have it. I have a piece of glass stuck in my finger and it's so small I can't get it out. THIS IS A WARNING!!!!! It didn't really fall, I had one side of it on the kitchen table. I called customer service and they treated me horrible. Acting like I just wanted a freebee.... I don't even want this thing in my house with my daughter if it can break this easily. Customer service also said you can't get replacement glass for it, even though in ebay replacement glass for the fire is everywhere and they sell... which obviously means I'm not the only one with this problem. Amazon will figure it out and all of us who have the old one will get screwed. Lost all respect for Amazon.

Title: XOOM wifi, it's all about the Android
Content: I've been using this for a few weeks now and it's fantastic. I already had an Android phone so I went for the wi-fi only version of this tablet thinking I can just tether it to my phone if I need data out and about and there is no wi-fi available. It gives my phones battery a punishment but otherwise works really well and saves me having two mobile data contracts. As for the tablet itself, it automatically installed all my favourite apps once I had signed in to my Google account. Adobe flash websites work fine but I'm still waiting for the memory card to be enabled. The new user interface is very good, maybe not as good as the iPad but it's still great and you can put widgets on the home screens and I'd be annoyed if I couldn't, all that screen space. The sound quality is alight, not bad but nothing spectacular, if it bothers you, use head phones. The graphics are impressive, I've become addicted to a 3D flight sym game on it and even my 10 year old nephew who's permanently playing games though the graphics were impressive. The interface is fast, plenty of storage but I still want the upgrade to get the SD reader going, found an app for everything I need although some of them need to be updated for tablet sized screens but I'm sure this will come with time. I also have the portfolio case, does a great job of protecting it but it's very chunky and annoyingly covers the power plug, unfortunately there isn't the huge selection of accessories you get with the iPad. I don't regret my purchase at all and I'm already using it everyday even if it is to read the news in bed, look things up when I'm on the sofa and play games.

Title: Kindle Fire is very cool
Content: I got the Kindle Fire for Christmas and after using it for a month now, I can say it is pretty good. I know everyone keeps comparing it to an iPad but it is not. I have checked out iPads and to me they are too expensive. They cost as much as my laptop which has almost 1tb of memory and does way more than an ipad. But the Kindle Fire is the perfect price. I have not had problems with web pages loading too slowly that some complain about. They load plenty fast for me. Comic books just look great on the Kindle Fire! And books read very well also, I don't have a problem with reading on the screen, my eyes seem to handle it well with out getting too tired. The apps work really well, I have downloaded several games and other apps. They have tons of them. The one thing I wish it had was 3G connectivity. Some apps only work while connected through wifi. There are some birding apps that I would like to get for birding, but most hiking trails etc do not have wifi. I know the reasoning was because if people were streaming video over 3G it would slow everything down, you could just disable that capability if the Kindle is only connect through 3G.

Title: I LOVE THIS THING
Content: This is my 3rd Kindle- I gave my first one to my dad when I bought the one that had wi-fi. I gave the second one to my husband when I bought the Kindle Fire. There are a few things about it that I don't like, but those could be b/c I haven't learned to use it yet. Even with the few minor issues that I have with it, I would not trade my Kindle Fire for anything!

Title: The Kindle Fire in Europe
Content: I've owned my Kindle Fire for about 2 weeks now and I love that device but as I live in Europe it has a LOT of limitations! But I think I do not make the same expectations as many other people as it has been said more than 100 times... it's just a $199 device! I really like the design. I love reading books in my Kindle Fire. I don't have another Kindle but I guess I will buy a Kindle Touch later on for better experience with reading as after reading for long in the Fire, my eyes get tired. But I have read up to 3 hours straight on the Fire. It takes me 1 hour to go to school and I love the fact that you can just e-mail your Fire some documents and read it there. I do it all the time and read documents on the way to school (in the bus). And now with the exams going on, I put my glossaries there and continue reading at school when waiting for the exam to start. Don't need to carry any papers with me :) Today I found out that my dad owns a USB cable which I connect the Fire to my PC. So I was able to put some music onto the device :) Along with some apps downloaded outside Amazon Appstore. Which comes to my main disappointment! As I live in Europe, and therefore do not own a USA debit or credit card, I cannot download any apps from the Amazon Appstore, not even the free ones!! I don't own an iPhone or an android phone for that matter so I was hoping the Kindle would be able to satisfy my app game need... but the answer to that is no at the moment. I've downloaded some apps from other websites and all the games I've downloaded (f.ex. Angry Birds (all versions), Yoo Ninja, Doodle Fit, and Jelly Defense) haven't been able to work in the Fire. I was able to get the Evernote app, but any other app had some type of glitches so it wasn't usable to me (events in a calendar didn't save and alarm would get error right before alarming me). Before getting my Fire I had written down some apps I wanted to get and I was very excited which made me very disappointed when I found out that I wouldn't be able to get any of those apps... at least not through Amazon appstore. Now I only have Evernote. I wish Amazon would open their appstore soon to the "International" market or at least so people can download the FREE apps... To add to this, I'm not able to use my free month of Prime as I'm not able to watch the free films and tv shows as I live outside the US. I haven't been able to buy any music, not that I've been trying to much. I can buy magazines, but I wasn't really interested in those in the first place so I wouldn't have cared if I could buy those or not, but I can (so YAY). I often use the Fire when I have it close but don't want to go up to my room to get my PC. I often use it to surf the internet, especially Facebook. I really hope that Amazon will open the Appstore to International market soon as being unable to get apps was my main disappointment. Or at least let people download the free apps! Some might think that this review should not give the Kindle Fire four stars, I just love what the Fire will be able to do when not "closed" like it is now and I like what I'm able to do with the Fire even when it's closed. It doesn't bother me that it's only wi-fi. Even though I'm "addicted" to the internet, I don't need to connect to the internet outside my home, and if I do, I just use my phone. The Kindle Fire is an amazing device for just $199 and totally worth buying when you live in the US ;) And to the rest of the human race when they've opened everything else to the International market! :)

Title: Whoooooops.
Content: This was the product I wanted, it did all that I required, (ereader, net, notes etc.) but it kept turning on by itself. This would occur a couple times a day when I would leave it in suspend. I killed all apps that could turn it on and it still would do it. I called support and they said return it. I did and it took 11 days for the replacement to get here. It sat in Federal Way WA for days but that is usps's review :-) The new unit arrived and did the same thing as the first one so since I leave my units in sleep/suspend and can't have them turning on at the wrong time I returned it as well. Liked the unit very much but....

Title: Love it!!!
Content: This is the greatest ever! Easy to use, great color, and does everything and iPad does for much less money. This is more than a reader...its like a mini laptop. I loved it so much I have bought 2 more for friends.

Title: Wicked Awesome
Content: I got the Kindle Fire for Yule and I love it. This device does everything it is suppose to do. I can get connected to the internet with no problem anywhere I go that has Wi-Fi access. The Kindle Fire is easy to use. I highly recommended this device.

Title: Don't do It!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Content: As much as I love Windows 7, this has got to be one of the worst machines I have ever used. It takes 7 minutes to get to the desktop after you first power up. Archos claims 2 hours power on the battery when you're online. Baloney! I was lucky to get one even ehen I wasn't online. The touchscreen is very difficult. I practically had to shove my finger through the computer. The stylus? What a joke. It broke less than a week after I started using it.

Title: Samsung missed the boat
Content: For this price not only did they miss it by locking it for phone use BUT it has a HD 1080P Video player an a 720P Camcorder and uses a A/V cable for hooking it up to a TV, so you get no HD when you play it back on the TV!! Gee, for $500 you get 2010 high tech video with 1990 quality output. What a shame when cheap tablets such as the Coby M7015 and the Ematic eGlide have a HDMI output to watch videos on the TV in HD. And this is from a company that makes HD and 3D TV's!!! Also I went on line at Samsung and downloaded the manual and nowhere did I see how to turn off the 3G so I could use the WIFI only. And it didn't say in the part where the manual tells you how to turn the WIFI on (WLAN) if it turns the 3G off at the same time. Does this mean you have both running at the same time eating up your monthly 5G while you surf on the WIFI? Also T mobile has it for $299.99 - $50 rebate (total $249.99) with a 2 year plan for data only of $39.99 which is the cheapest I have found for a 5G plan with no overage charges!!!

Title: Excellent tablet, not enough apps
Content: The tablet is excellent. never had an issue with the software, hardware is sturdy, it's fast and it's the perfect size for business use. Everyone in our company uses it for our own purposes. I just wish they had more apps for blackberry... I'm still waiting...

Title: Samsung have ruined Android
Content: I'm selling the Galaxy Tab after 1 day of ownership, Samsung have ruined the Android OS. When will hardware manufacturers (who should just provide a platform for the OS I want) realise that I don't want their interpretation of the OS, with parts disabled and applications added to suit their needs. I want the Android market, with all apps available yet many I know exist aren't available on the Tab. I want to plug the device into any PC and have it recognised as a USB drive (making file transfers easy & universal), I don't want this functionality disabled so I have to download and install the 80mb, hopelessly buggy, Samsung Kies software to 'Sync' my device iTunes style. And I don't want a dozen (or more) pre-installed apps that I can't even uninstall. I knew about the bespoke charging/data cable before I purchased the device, but that's another irritation. So I'll sell it and take the loss, I have added Samsung to the list of manufacturers who's equipment I'll avoid.

Title: Not worth the $$$
Content: First, we purchased this assuming it had all of the features our Androids have but it does not. You can't get any of the software you are accustomed to on your typical Android. It uses GetJar versus the Market Place and that offers nothing. We found this out from a friend who bought it locally and she, too, was returning hers. Meanwhile, ours was in the process of being shipped. So, having not liked the one we ordered we went to Costco and purchased the Vizio which we are very happy with. The Vizio is a typical Android set up with all of the expected features. The PanDigital is nothing more than a paperweight in our opinion. I purchased mine through the vendor SF Enterprises here on Amazon. Once I received the box, I requested a return but they ignored me. I had to file an AtoZ claim in order to get any response....which is taking forever to get rectified. I have now learned to never buy from anyone on Amazon unless they have a selling history, which they did not.

Title: Better Mix
Content: i'm returning my new Kindle Fire because i have other devices that are a better mix for me: a Kindle keyboard model for dedicated reading and a Google Chromebook for most everything else, including emailing and browsing in bed. (I also have a couple of laptops and desk tops, which i don't use much, anymore.) My biggest personal dissatisfaction with Fire is that its screen is too small. (I'm aware, of course, that many people will find Fire's small screen a plus.) My Chromebook does not suffer from the small screen limitation and, mostly for that reason, i find it much easier to use than Fire. (By the way, used Google Chromebook prototypes(CR-48) are available on many Craigslists for less than $200.) I also had an iPad for 6 months but it flunked the productivity test for me because of its lack of a physical keyboard. I do admire Fire's many features but they are not important to me. For example, I still prefer watching movies on a large screen TV. If i didn't have a Chromebook, i might be more susceptible to Fire's many charms. But i do. UPDATE: new social phenomena. Nearly 2400 customer reviews have been posted here in less than a week and a lot of the reviews are very long and detailed. I've never seen anything like it. What is going on with this? What is it about the K Fire that causes so many people to write so extensively. I have a theory: these K Fire buyers are literate people --primarily book readers--who can read and write; and there is something about the Fire that inspires them to do so. Obviously these customer reviewers are a biased sample not at all representative of the general population, which is only semi literate, at best, and can only tweet short responses with their thumbs. Alternative theories welcome. UPDATE 2: Bum Rap department. i've noted lots of criticism of KF for One Click Ordering and not being able to delete Gmails. One Click can be turned off at AMZ account page. Gmails can be deleted at Gmail site. These are not KF problems.

Title: Kindle Fire
Content: I really like the Kindle Fire and as apps are incresed can see me using the Kindle fire more then I ever used my Kindle DX (which by the way I read on a daily bases). My only complaint is that the Kindle Fire only works off of Wi Fi so if your in an area with no WiFi available you can not download new books or stream video. The wispernet was an awesome aspect of the other Kindle e-readers. Other then the WiFi aspect the Kindle fire is AWESOME!!!

Title: just want some more options from Kindle Fire
Content: I am very disappointed that the Kindle Fire does not have the usb option that will allow using with keyboard base nor webcam nor microphone.

Title: Don't get cheated and don't buy this ...
Content: I am not going to describe this item in great details - I'll just say that I was chasing it for quite a long time really dreaming of having big Tablet which is NOT Apple iPad. When I received this Archos, I was absolutely ready to forgive some of the inefficiencies of Android OS, knowing that it is really a new device and not all bugs have been captured so far. But what I really expected is to have no problems using this device as a basic entertainment tool and to watch movies, listen to audio tracks and rarely surf internet using Wi-Fi. Problem came unexpectedly - this piece of ... CAN NOT play MOVIES! You will not find this information in any official specifications, so this will be a complete surprise for you. To be absolutely fair, it CAN'T play movies with AC3 soundtracks (99% of all new movies now) and it CAN do it with third-party software players, that you can download for free from Android market, but in this case this unit will lag, movies will be stopping unexpectedly and the unit will extremely warm up as long as it will use SOFTWARE decoding that is not really optimal. If you want to use the powerful CPU of this unit and have a hardware decoding of these movies, you will HAVE TO BUY additional piece of software FROM ARCHOS (!) called AC3 Codec for around $20 or so. The thing that I'm mostly afraid now is what are the other things that I'll have to buy in advance for this inexpensive, BUT SHAREWARE device to operate properly and do what it is intended to do and how much money will I have to spend in order to make it work at least close to the way iPad works. The first day after I got this Archos 101 I really wanted to buy several Archos units for my wife and my mum. Now I'd better add 200 more bucks and buy them iPad that will play all movies without any hassle. Congratulations Archos, due to your greed for 20 bucks for this 'AC3 codec' you've just lost an opportunity to sell me at least two more devices that I was almost about to buy. Except for this, I can admit that this Archos is not bad. So, if you don't plan to watch movies on it :-), you can surely buy it. It is worth money asked for it :-) It's really sleek and lightweight and might serve you well as an e-book or an e-newspaper.

Title: MY KINDLE FIRE
Content: Love it; Love it; Love it! I got the Kindle Fire for Christmas. I've had a Kindle for a number of years and loved it but the Kindle Fire is even better! I like the features and I REALLY like the size. It fits in all my purses which means I can easily take it anywhere.

Title: Just wow and jealousy
Content: i bought the ipad for my husbands birthday. he uses it around the house and for his college work. im so jealous! i want my own now. not only can we play games on this pad-i can window shop online to my hearts content, email my friends n family easily and in a more fun way. i can download millions of pdf's and other ebooks, store them on the pad and read whenever i want. my husband uses it for making notes about his classes, applications galore for math, homework tracking and so many other little things i have yet to peek at! ive since given up my old laptop to share the ipad and our desktop until we can afford MY ipad. we seriously love it and its cute to watch my husband get all excited and show me something new the ipda can do for him. right now im watching him play Angry Birds on the couch as i write this. we're getting ready for bed. we added netflex to the ipad so we can snuggle up in bed and hide under the covers like kids while we watch movies. tonight is my night- i want to see The Nutcracker Ballet. lol

Title: All perfect except the sound
Content: This equipment is great in all the functions, installing software and incredible video quality and use. The problem is the poor sound that have to send audio to another equipment or amp.

Title: If you love Amazon u won't be disappointed!!
Content: Just received this as a Valentine's day gift from my hubby, and so far so good. I've only had it a few hours but in that short time I've grown to love Zuri(yes I named my Kindle fire) .. I'm so excited to read my books, listen to music, play games, surf the web and explore the numerous other things I haven't found yet. I must say I'm not an Apple user so I really can't compare to ipad, but I love amazon and I love my kindle fire... Best gift ever!!! Loyal Amazon customer

Title: Kindle Fire
Content: The Kindle Fire I got from Amazon was my second Kindle. So far I like it very much and I'm sure I will like it even better when I learn how to take advantage of all of the features it has. I'm one of those people who would rather learn something "hands on" than to read it out of a manual. This will take a little longer. I also bought one of these for my daughter and sister as well as my own two. They were both very happy with their's and have gotten a lot of use out of it.

Title: Love my Kindle Fire! Wish it had parental controls
Content: Santa brought our 7 year old a Kindle fire for Christmas. I loved it so much, I bought one for myself. The device is very user friendly, and I love being able to check out book from the local library as well as all the internet and app features it has. My only negative about the Kindle fire is that for my son, I would like some type of parental control feature. There is currently not any security type feature on this device so we had to have the internet connection locked with a password, and we do all the adding of books, apps and music for him. Some parents may find this silly however the internet is wonderful, but not everything on there is for a 7 year-olds eyes. I highly recommend the kindle fire! Love it in our family!

Title: 3G not supported
Content: I was going to purchase kindle fire but I changed my mind the reason that it doesn't come with 3G which is then useless for me I wont have internet everywhere I go ,

Title: Kindle Fire Connected Me to the World!
Content: My HP laptop had been out of commission for several months, so obtaining a Kindle that allowed me access to email, web browsing, facebook, movies and books was nothing short of a miracle! The price seemed reasonable, too! However, Kindle is not a full fledged computer, so do not expect it to be so. The touch screen interface is easy to adapt to, but clumsy and inept at long posts or editing blogs. There are website formats out there that still do not recognize the technology of the device. The auto spell correction feature can drive you into a full mental breakdown until you have entered all the words in there that it does not recognize. You can turn this feature "off" but somehow it does not stay off. As long as your typing is slow and steady, and you check your typing, it works fine. Everything else is a blast. The videos and movies stream really well. The books are great. I love shopping at Amazon, so that works out fine. There are a lot of apps available to customize your device to you. I cannot compare to any other devices, because I have not tried them. Kindle Fire does beat trying to surf the web with a cell phone, however. All things considered, the Kindle Fire is user-friendly right out of the box; a nice size, not too little or too big; and does exactly what it was made to do.

Title: Good V1.0 Product - Missing some KEY hardware.
Content: Overall Kindle Fire seems very good after using it for the last few days. I do think it's a good product, but it's far from perfect as any 1.0 version would be. Some things that I've found that I was not so pleased with include: [1] I was surprised that there were two speakers at the top of the device (in portrait mode), but all the video watching is in landscape mode putting both speakers on the left. [2] I cannot use it exclusively in portrait mode. Many of the experience do not rotate and force me to switch back to holding it in landscape mode. [3] It is heavier than I expected. Given it's small size, I had not expected it to be fatiguing. It pretty much forces you to hold it with both hands, especially in landscape mode. [4] The PDF reader is awkward and seems kludgy; it has very few controls. For example, I would like to search both within PDF documents and across a set of PDF documents. [5] Browsing through music seems... less refined than I would have liked. Compared to the Apple offerings, this part of the Kindle Fire UI is weak. [6] All of the "shopping experiences" are much smoother than the rest of the UI. (yeah, I know, surprise surprise). [7] I would have loved to use this as a programmable remote control in my living room -- this would keep it in constant usage and generate impulse buys. [8] Where is the 3G support, this seems like an obvious way to make this device even more mobile rather than mostly housebound. [9] Where is the support for Exchange server email? I would have like to carry this around at home and work as a REAL email client. [10] Where is the microphone and camera so I can make telephone calls OR do video chat on my "SIP VOIP" client -- instead of carrying a cellphone. I'm sure future versions of the Kindle products will be even better, but for $200 _now_ this is a great toy to use when you're not near a desktop and your phone is too small. I would grade it 4 stars out of 5 possible.

Title: Could Have Been A Contender - Key Component Missing
Content: First, don't compare this to an iPad. It's apples and oranges, and there is no comparison. If you want the capabilities of an iPad, don't buy this. But, when this came out, I thought it would be just what I was looking for, after an unsatisfactory experience with Barnes and Noble's Nook, but instead, it is just another tablet missing a key component: an SD or Micro SD card slot for expandability. Anyone who has any experience with tablets, iPads or iPods, knows it doesn't take long to fill up 8 GB. So, that being said, this tablet is not a contender.

Title: A gift for my husband.
Content: I purchased the Kindle Fire for my husband who is greatly enjoying it. He is thrilled that he can download his favorite music and purchase his favorite books and download movies without having to leave the house.

Title: Kindle Fire Full Color Screen, Multi-Touch Display
Content: Purchased product as a gift for someone else. They had a few problems getting it to work. Contacted Amz Tech Support because we wanted to exchange it, Registration Button was not working and touch screen was not responding properly. AMZ Tech Support was terrific and they helped to get Kindle Fire working with the newest software upgrade. Touch screen still seems to be difficult, at times, but its getting easier. Overall, nice device. Easily downloaded a book and was able to contact the internet etc... Seems like its going to be a lot of fun.

Title: Do your research before buying
Content: The only reason I gave this product 2 stars is because my 6 year old twins like it, but often complain about it not "working right", it freezes alot and is very limited to apps that you can download. My 11 year will use it but only to read, because she says it doesn't work as fast as her iPod touch or my iPad. I knew before ordering the 3 tablets that it wasn't by any means an iPad, iPod, Nook or Kindle. But by all means it should at least do what it's supposed to. I also ordered stylus and they have helped tremendously, it's easier to use with its resistive touchscreen. It's a work in process trying to add apps that are compatible. I tried to reach worldwide and they have not responded yet, it's been almost 2 weeks and still no response. So if you do get this product DON'T ORDER FROM WORLDWIDE! They can go KICK ROCKS, to put it nicely.

Title: Great tablet & Price! Good Hardware, much better if you "hack" it.
Content: I was concerned about purchasing this tablet due to all the negative reviews out there about the ROM/software and screen angle. I purchased in June 2011, and found the ROM/ Android operating system to be acceptable after the first over the air update to version 3588. I used it a week or two with that stock ROM and really didn't have any problems, so was hesitant to do any tweaking or hacking. The tablet works with flash 10.1 to 10.3 contrary to many of the reviews. There is a link to download it from Viewsonic's website ([...]). As far as the screen, it is really a good screen, but it seems like it works better if you hold it upside down. Holding it normally, in landscape view, It needs to be viewed straight on, or from the top down. If you tilt the top away from you, it gets dimmer, and doesn't look good. As long as you hold it flat to your view you are fine, but after a while the weight gets to you and you start tilting it away. At that point, just flip it over, and you can see it fine from the bottom view (tilted slightly away from your eye). Only problem with this is the switches are in a different position than normal, but I haven't had any real difficulty with that. So the screen is not really a big problem and it actually looks great from the right angles, or holding it upside down in landscape mode. Also during this initial 2 weeks time I was researching on the internet all the various options for 3rd party ROMs to use on the Viewsonic GTablet device. There are many choices in ROMs for the GTablet, from Android 2.2, which it comes with, to 2.3 and 2.4, and also alpha or beta versions with Android Honeycomb 3.0. Anyway, after a while using the default Viewsonic ROM the device stopped being able to find my music. It just quit showing up in the music player. I tried other music players, and copying off and back on the music files, but still no luck. Anyway, I finally got frustrated with this, and decided to take the leap and install a new ROM. It took me 3 attempts to get it to boot properly, having to use both nvflash (needs Windows USB drivers, which were a little difficult to get installed in Win7-64bit) and Clockworkmod. These are both developer tools for changing the ROM. Anyway, there was a lot of information on the internet about the process, and many had tried and run into similar problems before, so a few quick google searches and I got the new ROM installed. I went with a stable version of Andoid 2.3, along with some kernal tweaks that allow overclocking the processor. It really flies now, and works even better than before. It also works with the Google android marketplace once hacked. Of course the Amazon Android marketplace is also very useful and I have made a few purchases there. ;-) Anyway, I am very happy to get a 10.1" high resolution Android tablet for $300 ($375 with nice carry case and extra 16GB SDHC card (again, from Amazon). It also has made my previous purchase of an internet radio, ipod touch, and Nook ereader not necessary, so those items will be going up on ebay soon. Who knows when I'm done, I may have my total net cost down to less than $200. That would really be awesome!! So if you have a technical bent, and have possibly hacked or cracked devices before, are willing to keep trying until you get it done (ROM change), do not be afraid to purchase a GTablet. During June 2011, the Gtablets actually dropped to a low price of $249, but quickly turned around and are no longer available for much below $300. I think people are starting to realize it's a great deal on a great tablet.

Title: I LIKE IT
Content: This does what I want it to. Seems to drop my Wi-Fi signal occasionally but overall I am happy for only $199 bucks. Doesn't look like it will be easy to read on in the sunlight but oh well, I have my older Kindle for that. Very sturdy, well made product. Just need to find a case for it now that doesn't cost an arm and a leg. Do wish it had a camera on it so I could list my eBay auctions on it...

Title: Great little device
Content: I love my Kindle Fire. I took it right out of the box & all I had to do to set it up was enter the key for my wireless modem & it registered itself & knew who I was. Title: almost flawless
Content: after hearing so many conflicting reviews from people i sucked it up and decided to get one of these. quickly i learned that it was a great decision. i absolutely love my kindle fire. its back lit so if the power goes off i can still read my books (hey, when you live in an area with a number of tornados thats a must) and yet i can put the dimmer on to get that paper book tint which is easier on the eyes. when watching a movie it takes over the entire screen and contrary to what ive heard from people the sound is just fine. i can watch it on the couch with a friend and we can both hear it with ease. The picture is just as sharp as my dvd player. Internet quickness, people have complained, you must know that this goes through your wi fi. if your internet connection is not good than your kindle fire internet quickness will not be good. i have a good internet service and so it goes with the kindle fire. that was a major concern when i was shopping around with readers. i love the music player because im able to listen and read at the same time. i also love that i can buy alot of books through amazon free of charge. it also comes with a nice dictionary already on the shelf. okay everything you buy is going to have a glitch. Headphones... i havent googled it much but it appears that i cant use my regular ear buds with this. glitch 2 but not really a glitch. this is not a dvd player. you cannot skip from scene to scene without scrolling and its time consuming to find just that right spot and you have to allow it around 30 seconds to reload. easy solution is that the pause button is so convenient. this device is so easy to understand that you very well may not need instruction but when questions arise there is an info booklet on it. the set up is quick. it comes with a little charge but you will need to to plug it in during the set up because there is not enough charge for that. after its got a full battery the battery life is very good. i use mine throughout the day so much and it keeps a battery leaving me still enough time to watch a movie later just keep an eye on the battery in the top right corner. one problem people have had is the on button. lol easy solution to that. turn it over. its of no importance that the kindle imprint on the back is facing in the right direction. i have ocd and im not even concerned with that. its a toggeler. you turn it and it goes to the direction that you want to watch it in. if your watching a film just dont hold down the button. the kindle reader does not have page numbers, though that doesnt bother me it may bother some BUT it does have a line and a percentage so you do know how far you are through the book. me, i enjoy my books more because im not constantly having the page number telling me how far i am through it. i know right now im reading the girl who kicked the hornets nest on mine and if there is an * next to the word you can click on it and it flips over to an explanation of who they are talking about. to go back you simply click on the blue again and there you go. i love my kindle fire and will encourage anyone who is bumfuzzled about wether or not to go this route to take the plunge. its by far my favorite toy. the first day of using one youd think i was a child on christmas day and im still having so much fun with it. Don't forget to download an anti virus ap. They are free under aps store.

Title: Archos 5 for Anime and Manga Fans
Content: I previously owned the Archos 5 160GB without android, was quite pleased with it, and decided to upgrade to the Archos 5 160 with android. I mostly use the device to watch anime, read manga, and listen to music. My first impression after I opened the box and turned it on was "this is crap" since it froze after 5 min. However, after installing the new firmware it works like a charm. The biggest plus for me was that the device now has mkv video playback. Yes, it works with mkv files with subs (big letters and easy to read) and the video quality is superb. The downside is RMVB playback is not available, but a lot of programs can convert the files now. Manga viewing is quite good with both downloaded images and manga online. Overall, the device is great for what I want it to do. The only problem I have is with the battery life, I highly recommend downloading an app to quickly adjust screen brightness and wifi usage.

Title: Now that I have one, I love it!
Content: I wanted an Andriod tablet but couldn't justify getting one, until a recent flight home. I travel frequently and like to watch videos on my laptop to pass the time. That's fine in the airport, and if I can get an exit row seat. On this trip home I wasn't so lucky; trying to watch videos on the plane was cumbersome. I finally talked myself into getting a tablet and picked the A500. I don't care for Apple products because they are too restrictive. This has nothing to do with the current iOS; their products have always been that way because that's part of their marketing strategy. Apple's products force you to use Apple services, like iTunes. I had been comparing the different Andriod tablets out of curiosity, and this one was the best in my opinion. There are a number with 10.1" screens that are almost identical in performance and core features, but the Acer Iconia tablets stands out. I like that is has a micro-HDMI port, a micro-SD slot, a micro-USB slave port, and a full sized USB host port for connecting external devices. I bought the 16GB tablet and installed a 32GB micro-SD in it, and copied media directly onto it from my laptop. I bought a Verbatim 16GB USB flash drive for it that is so small I can leave it plugged in. I tried plugging in a 120GB hard drive and it read that, too! My strategy is to put media onto the micro-SD card that I want to keep on the tablet (like pictures), and use my 16GB USB flash drive for media that I will delete after enjoying (podcasts & videos). I got a nice wallet for it, and also some screen protectors. I highly recommend the wallet, but not the screen protector. The A500's glass screen is so easy to clean with the included microfiber cloth. Not so now with the screen protector installed.

Title: A Very Handy Tablet! UPDATED REVIEW March 26, 2012
Content: **UPDATE MARCH 26, 2012** I came back to Amazon to update my review now that I've had the Vizio VTab for 4 months. Interestingly enough, there were not as many reviewers posting about problems when I originally researched and purchased my Vizio as there are now. Many reviewers are complaining about the battery life and charging issues. I never had charging issues or battery life issues until a few weeks ago. Then these two issues happened (went wrong) after upgrading to Honeycomb. I do not know if there is a connection between the two or whether they are separate issues. I will say that just a couple of weeks prior to installing the upgrade, I noticed that I was having issues powering the device on. Other than that, I figured I was not holding the button properly for bringing the tablet out of hibernate. Nonetheless, my tablet no longer powers on as of last night. Very sad indeed as I ABSOLUTELY still love the tablet and will not reduce the rating I originally gave it. Obviously, there is a problem and I hope Vizio isn't going broke by giving free replacements. Bottom line, it's obviously a flagship product in beta. :( Purchase at your own risk and know that until Vizio corrects the problems, it IS a purchase risk. Sorry to say but true. I don't want to have to 'return' my product as it does have personal data on it. Honeycomb is (was) working well. I loved the update and afterward I charged the unit, played a few games (2 hrs or less); turned the tablet to hibernate (with plenty of battery left according to the icon), and left it until the following night. I could ALWAYS get 2 to 3 evening of play/work from the tablet (estimating 8 hours of constant time or 2-3 days of a couple hours each day with standby time in between). It would not turn on but would flicker as though it was attempting to turn on. Put it on the charger and the batter was in the red. It should not have been in the red as it reported 90% battery left when it was put into hibernate. Same thing happened the next night after charging it all day. Was good for a couple of hours, hibernated, turned on this a.m. and it won't power on, flicker, nada, nottin'. On the charger now hoping for a miracle. I will update after I figure out how to resolve. ================ ORIGINAL REVIEW: If you read the description for this Vizio tablet, you'll find it spot on. It is ANDROID driven and we love Android. ;) My husband set it up to work as a remote for our (Vizio) television and he says it works great. Notice the "he said" as I don't often have access to the remote in the man-cave. ;) I'd like to make a couple of comments in reference to a couple of earlier reviews found posted here. 1) This tablet is WiFi only. If you plan on using its GPS feature, that might be a mute app without WiFi. It does not have 'mobile access' like your mobile phone. It does not require a mobile plan and it can't be used with a mobile plan. Therefore, any connection to the WWW is via WiFi connection only. Think of it as a mini laptop with a WiFi connection. Hence, the less expensive this tablet is in comparison to those that you can use with a mobile plan. 2) Regarding a Facebook app. I do not recommend Facebook on this. If you just want to check in and do limited activity, there is an app called Seismic that can act as a hub and connect you with Twitter, Facebook and a few others. It will stream the 'recent activity' of these social media sites. You can Tweet, Like, share, comment and more. Better than fooling around with security issues that Facebook hasn't remedied yet. We immediately purchased a 32GB SDHC Class 10 micro card to take full advantage of the extra space and install apps to the card as opposed to eating up the 2GB available on board the tablet. If you have already installed apps on the tablet's memory while waiting to spring for the 32GB card (or smaller), not a problem. You can easily transfer the apps from the tablet to the micro card later, with the touch of a finger. Why a Class 10? It's still compatible and a bit speedier than a Class 4 or 6. If you don't care about any of that, go for an SDHC card with less than a Class 10 rating and save some money in the process. This makes a very nice household helper. You can store a budget, a grocery list, recipes, notes to / from the spouse or kids; list your contacts, phone numbers, medicines, whatever you would like it to do for you in ways to make your life simpler or easier, you will have a friend with this little helper. Battery life is as it states. However, if you are using it a lot throughout the day, it may run down a bit quicker BUT it still has a longer life than you'd expect. We get a couple of days in standby mode (little use) before we have to charge it again. If you are a Netflix member, you can use the Netflix app to access your account (in a WiFi location) and watch movies in bed! Yaaay! :) Have fun with it!

Title: Great tablet if you unlock its potential........
Content: I originally purchased my HP Touchpad when it went on firesale after being discontinued... While I was very impressed with WebOS, I found the selection of apps less than impressive and after seeing HP all but abandon any support for my Touchpad with updates and apps, it quickly became a clock that sat on its touchstone charger for months at a time as my Ipad went back to being my daily use tab.... Well, I finally decided to see how well Android would work on my Touchpad since I'd been reading good things as far the progress that's been made with getting Android (Cyanogenmod9) which is essentially Ice Cream Sandwich Android OS 4.0. You do not lose WebOS as it will become a dual boot OS so don't worry. The instructions for getting Android on your Touchpad are readily available on the web, so I won't go into that here, but I will say with complete confidence, JUST DO IT. I now have an essentially fully functioning Android tablet running ICS(Ice Cream Sandwich), with complete access to the hundreds of thousands of apps available for Android, and oh, have you ever wished there was a Netflix app for your Touchpad? Ever wished you could play "Angry Birds" on your Touchpad? I think you get the hint.. Now be warned, this modification is still being improved and in "Alpha" phase with nightly improvement builds, but it has handled everything I've thrown at it so far!! Now I love and use my Touchpad as much as my Ipad, and it truly is the tablet it should have been under WebOS.....

Title: Depends on what you compare it to
Content: After watching the Amazon presentation for the kindle fire, I was expecting it to work similar to a smaller ipad. I was way off. The Silk browser takes between 15 and 20 times as long to load a web page, compared to my ipad on the same network. I timed several webpages loading on both at the same time. Email works, but takes about double the time to load, and won't let you pinch to zoom, which is a problem because of the small font and screen size. The pinch to zoom works on other apps choppy, when it works at all, compared to the ipad that always works perfectly. The app store has nowhere near as many or as good apps, and way less free apps compared to the Apple app store. In short, for 40% as much money as an ipad, you get 50% the size, 50% the storage, 10% the apps, and 7% the speed. In other words, the ipad is a far better deal. I love my kindle for reading, but I can't thing of any use for my new kindle fire, except maybe a $200 paper weight. ******** UPDATE ********** I really want to like this product. Amazon is my favorite merchant and I am hoping to find an ipad type tablet that I can use with my class. (i teach high school.). A class set of ipads is more than I can afford, but a class set of kindle fires is more reasonable. Using the kindle fire for a couple weeks, I am still disappointed, but.... If ylou compare the fire to anipad, that is like Mike Tyson boxing a 3-year old: not a fair fight. The ipad is so far beyond the fire, in speed ease of use, apps, etc. But, the more fair comparison is kindle fire vs. Ipod touch. Both are the same price. Here too it is not a fair fight, the fire is far superior to the ipod touch for surfing the web, checking email, watching videos, playing games, etc. (everything except listening to music and portability). Also, the selection of educational apps is literally growing by the day. I just downloaded a couple good science apps today. And, the free app of the day is fun. If you want a tablet, you want an ipad. If you think the fire is a $200 ipad, ypu are kidding yourself. But, if $200 is all you are able or willing to spend and you want a mini tablet, the fire beats the ipod touch hands down. I am keeping my fire, but holding off on buying a class set of tablets for now.....

Title: A wonderful addition to my tech toys.
Content: I got the Iconia Tab for Father's day this year, and I really love it. I have been using it extensively for IM, web surfing, playing games, and watching videos. I have really had no complaints. (None that can be laid at the feet of the device, anyway.) The Honeycomb operating system is elegant and easy to use. Acer's additions are also nice, and not terribly intrusive. There are some app 'groups' to make your experience a bit more streamlined, and the Acer Clear.fi media sharing software. Older Android apps work as well, with a few exceptions. However, once you find some tablet-optimized apps, you'll find yourself hungry for more. There's really no comparison between the slick UI of a tablet app like TweetComb and the "everything is full screen" experience of an Android 2.x app. Typing is surprisingly comfortable. If the tablet is resting on a stand or easel case, it's very simple. If you plan to work mostly with the device in-hand, I would suggest checking out Thumb Keyboard or something similar that lets you type at the edges of the screen. (I'm in the beta for Swiftkey X for Tablets and it's easy to use.) Games are responsive and pretty. I have played Angry Birds and Galaxy on Fire 2 extensively, and the experience is very smooth. The built in USB host port has been useful already, for transferring files off my USB thumb drive. Video takes a bit more work, but is still pretty easy. Out of the box, the system is compatible with H.264 (mp4) video. If you have a library of video files you'd like to use that don't match that, RockPlayer, VPlayer, and more are all out there waiting to be installed from the market. I gave this system a 4 instead of a 5 because of the power adapter. It's a proprietary power adapter, so there is no charging it from the PC. In addition, the cord is really too short for comfortable use while plugged in. However, battery life is great. I forgot to charge mine last night and am on hour 16 of use, with about 20% battery remaining.

Title: iPad2
Content: I'll be the first to admit, I love toys. Gadgets, gizmos, anything electronic will catch my attention. THese toys are great, but my fascination is not longterm. Too soon after I spend my money on the latest "must have" the toy finds its way to the shelf as I move on. I held off on purchasing an iPad2 because of the cost and because I was fearful it would spend $730 for something I would later stash away nver to use again. Nothing could be further from the truth. I've had my iPad2 for about three months now and I love it more each day. I'm using it everyday for several hours. I use it for my work, and for fun. I listen to music, watch movies, and play with fun, educational apps. I have work-related apps. I use it for my local government role so I do not need to print paper forms and other official documents. I buy apps but I love the free ones. It is a challenge to find useful apps for free. I can manage my investments with it. I can use Google Earth and travel the world. I no longer consider my iPad2 just a toy. It is an intregal part of my life as I can quickly check emails and get headline news. I can follow sports teams and have my music collection. It is awkward to bring along during hikes, but I do have it in my car for the music. I have podcasts and iBooks. It will never replace my laptop, it will not replace my Kindle, but I cannot see myself without my iPad2. I strongly recommend the iPad2 to anyone who is even remotely considering buying one. You will be amazed at the number of uses you will find for it.

Title: One of the best tablets in the market
Content: Bought this Acer Iconia a500 tablet a couple of weeks ago and I am really glad I made this choice. The first day I received it I updated it via wifi with the Honeycomb 3.1 release. This tablet is stylish and very well built. Here are the pros and cons that I have found so far: PROS ------- Excellent capacitive LCD screen, watchable from different angles Very well built device 2 USB ports (Normal size USB and Micro USB) 1 HDMI port 1 micro SD that supports High Capacity up to 32GB 32GB of internal storage 1 GB RAM 2 cameras (one of 5 Megapixels in the back and the other of 2 Megapixels for video conferences) Great 3d graphics performance with the NVidia chipset CONS ------- Some of these models have the microphone burried inside of the top of the screen, which makes it difficult for it to capture your voice while you are talking in a call through Skype. Apparently Acer corrected this in the newer a500 releases. Another flaw but that is related to the Honeycomb OS, is that Honeycomb devices are not recognized as a massive storage device when you connect them to Windows. Thus, this brings sync issues with some programs that require to access the device through a drive letter.

Title: Addicted to the Kindle Fire
Content: This tablet is awesome! It's simple, easy to use, and so much fun. As for the complaints regarding "no camera"....well...that's what you get when you buy a tablet for $200. I've also read some reviews regarding the "shut down" button accidentally being pressed. Don't know how this happens really....I've only had it happen once and the Kindle Fire simply goes in sleep mode and you can just turn it back on. The absolutely BEST thing about this product is that there were a few glitches at first, and Amazon was responsible enough to listen to customer complaints and do an on air update for free. Most other companies wouldn't have cared. KUDOS AMAZON!!! Remember....you're not getting volume control buttons on the outside of the device and you're not getting a camera...but this is a small sacrifice to make for something so affordable. I read books, surf the internet, watch videos, listen to music, and play games on my Kindle every day and have a very hard time putting it down. Save your money and forget about the iPad.

Title: Ok, I guess.
Content: For something that's $199, the Fire works pretty well. Internet browsing works fine, the display is pretty good, and it offers a whole bunch of apps in the app store. I've only had my Fire for a few weeks or so (it was a gift), and so far these are some of the things I don't like about it. -WiFi connection problems. I've noticed that a lot of people have been running in to this problem. My Fire used to connect to WiFi at home perfectly fine, but now it refuses to connect AT ALL. Kind of bugs me, considering the fact that I just want to download my books/apps and use the internet. -Isn't as "loaded" function wise as other tablets. But that's expected from the price, so I guess I'll just have to suck it up and deal with it. -No buttons. Being someone who's used to pressing a home button on an iPhone to get back to the home screen, I do find it a little annoying that I have to press the touch screen home button all the time (especially when I find myself having to practically stab the screen to get it to actually work). Also, it would be nice to have volume buttons on the side. -Sluggish touch screen. Sometimes it works great, sometimes it sucks. Not really comparable to an iPad/phone. -Can't change the background/splash screens/whatever they're called. Pretty self explanatory. -1Click purchasing. I kind of hate the fact that you can't use a gift card for your 1Click auto billing to buy things directly from the Fire. It's a little annoying that I have to get on another device to buy, then wait for it to download on my Kindle. I do realize that 1Click is pretty convenient, but as a teenager, I don't have a credit card, and don't plan on registering the credit card of a parent any time soon. There's a reason why I got the gift card in the first place. -Not a whole lot of storage. Maybe it's just me, but I don't quite feel like 8GB is enough. I'm not saying that I don't like this thing, I really do. The Fire is a pretty great product for its price, although I am looking forward to seeing where Amazon is going to take this next.

Title: Great Tablet for the Price!
Content: This tablet is a Great deal! I am very happy with the performance and the selection of apps is nice.

Title: Great tablet, Great price
Content: I love my Acer Iconia! It works very well for surfing the web and using apps. I love reading books on it, too. I can even play movies and TV shows without a problem. It charges very fast and holds a charge for several days for me (I took it out of town for the weekend, used it in the car for several hours both ways, and didn't have to charge it until after I got home). I don't think it has the best camera picture quality, but I didn't buy it to be a camera and as I am never without my phone or real camera, I don't have a problem with that. Sound quality is pretty good, and reaction to the touch screen is good as well. The picture is clear and crisp. I can easily download apps, books, music, and other things with wifi and have never had a problem. I think the only think I dislike is that the screen shows fingerprints easily, but that can be said about most touch-screen products so it just comes with the territory I suppose.

Content: Purchased this tablet to test a few apps I'm currently developing, and because I didn't want to follow the crowd and buy an ipad2. In case you didn't already know, it is rated by consumer reports as the best android tablet on the market. It has better resolution 1280?00 screen vs the iPad 2's 1024x768, and the battery life is similar. Also, the Samsung Tablet has a better camera, a front-facing 2.0 megapixel (vs iPad 2's 0.3 megapixel) camera and rear-facing 3.0 megapixel (vs iPad 2's 0.7 megapixel) camera. Would not recommend relying on this camera, but if you're in a pinch it will do the job. Additionally, the Tab 10.1 is a negligible 0.03 lbs lighter and 0.2mm thinner than the iPad 2. While the iPad 2 is clearly the more trendy product, the Samsung Galaxy tab is a great choice if you're looking for an alternative to the iPad. Title: Christmas present
Content: 1. beautiful color 2. audio is a 10! music and books sound really great. 3. ereader is easy to use with lots of options [font size, etc] 4. apps are fun and useful 5. it is very easy to use. I use it for audio books, ebooks, web search, movies[netflex, etc],games, listening to music while I read.Pandora works great on here, so does Audible.com. I've downloaded books from our library, it was easy. I copyed and pasted a movie [mp4] and music to it and both worked great. Using the cloud option works fine and keeps your books and music easy to get to. If you copy and paste to the Kindle and delete, files don't go to the cloud, they are deleted, but easy to put back on if wanted again. I've really taken advantage of the prime option, i've watched classic tv shows and movies; getting 2 day delivery is great too! Amazon keeps adding apps that makes my Kindle Fire even more useful. Title: OMG
Content: My Kindle Fire arrived in 2 days after I ordered it and it lives up to it's reputation. It's like a smaller version of iPad but for what I need it for it works well. Sometimes I don't want to take my computer everywhere I go and this is a great substitute for sending and receiving email because of it's size and easier to use then my iPhone. It also saves me room in my suitcase since I don't have to take any books along that I like to read, they're all in one place now. A little heavier then a kindle; after all it is a small computer so it makes sense. WOW! Easy to load apps and books from one spot. The sound could be a little louder but other then that it was a very nice surprise for the money!

Title: Updated review after a month and a half
Content: What I said in my original review is correct but I don't consider it a good value. The most disappointing thing is the battery life...I agree with the reviewer that said you are lucky if you get 3 hours, especially if you connect to the internet. The whole purpose of the tablet was to replace my kindle as a reader and have some additional portable feature. The short battery life makes it not very portable. I wish I would have known about the Kindle Fire and waited a couple of months, since I paid the same as the new Kindle and add the cost of the case and the microSD card. It came to over $240. On Aug 16 I wrote: Overall this multimedia tablet it a good value when compared to the cost of the ipad. First, be aware that the Amazon specs say it takes sd/sdhc cards so I purchased an sdhc 32gb card for $48 and found that the tablet only takes microsd cards. The other minus is that the Android system does not allow the installation of Flash or Silverlight, which means you cannnot view videos from Hulu, Netflix, or Amazon instant view. This was disappointing since I have accounts with all three. It does have an app to view youtube videos. Other than that it is good as an ereader with a Kindle app, for browsing the internet, playing games (many free game apps), getting your email, for your music, pictures and personal videos. I have only had the tablet a couple of days so there may be other uses that I have not mentioned.

Content: My sister received the new I-Pad for Mother's Day and after trying it for awhile I really wanted one myself but I wasn't willing to shell out $600 or whatever they're going for now. Title: Kindle Fire Great but UPS is Fallen Angel
Content: I pre-ordered a Kindle Fire even before the product 1st appeared on the main Amazon splash screen. Despite the naysayers, I love the product. Easy to use and carry. Great color. Very convenient for email checking, news, and reading books! Like it so much that since then I've bought two others as gifts for family members! I am disappointed though in UPS over the last couple of years. They appear to have lost common sense when making deliveries. Over all orders I place, not just including the Kindle Fire, more than 50% of the time UPS does not even ring the doorbell. The majority of time the deliveries come after dark and I am home, yet no courtesy ring. Due to that, one package sat out on the front porch all night long which is worrisome due to burglaries in the neighborhood. Fortunately nothing has been stolen, but I have to say I now hesitate to order items from Amazon due to the poor UPS customer service.

Title: Great Addition to E-Ink Tech Kindle
Content: I read constantly and if this was my first experience with the Kindle I would be devastated. The E-Ink technology used for the other versions of the Kindle (even the $79 Kindle) is far, far, far superior to the backlit display of the Fire for reading. If you read a lot, spend an extra $100 or so and get another Kindle in addition to this one. You won't regret it because reading with the e-ink tech is just as soothing as reading a paper book. After having my Kindle Fire for about three days I promptly ordered one for my niece for Christmas. I love the features - Facebook, email, streaming free movies and television shows. In addition to the movies and tv shows (I'm currently halfway through the first season of the now-cancelled "Saving Grace") I love that I can download and play music. It is very user friendly. My five year old twins keep confiscating my Kindle Fire to watch "Super Why" episodes, National Geographic, Sesame Street and kid-friendly movies. And yes, they do this all by themselves! A recent trip to the pediatrician was a real dream - my contagious little guys were happy to sit quietly and watch a movie. They are learning to read, and the children's books are incredible. But the biggest testimonial happened this morning. My hubby worked an overtime detail involved him sitting in his patrol car watching a construction site all night. He has a Kindle Keyboard 3G and was planning to take just that. Late last night, I quickly rented a movie I know he's been wanting to watch, spent 60 seconds showing him how to use my Kindle Fire and sent him on his way. My extremely NOT technology savvy hubby came home at 8 a.m. with a huge smile and announced: "I WANT ONE!" He watched his rented downloaded movie and then happily started watching free episodes of Star Trek DS-9 until his shift finally ended. Our other Kindle books downloaded right onto the Fire, but again, this is NOT the Kindle I will be using for most of my reading. But it is still oh so much fun and has a myriad of other uses! Don't waste your time or money on screen protectors - you don't need them. And I'm not happy with my case - I would prefer something that would allow the Kindle to stand up. But I'm still very happy with my Fire!

Title: Coby Kyros 8-Inch Android 2.2 4 GB Internet Touchscreen Tablet- MID8024-4G (Black)
Content: After reading all of these reviews, I really need to get on my soapbox..... First off, if you want an Ipad, or whatever tablet it is that you are thinking of, then by all means, go out and spend hundreds of dollars on it. Its your choice. PLEASE DON'T GIVE THIS TABLET BAD REVIEWS BASED ON THE FACT THAT YOU HAVEN'T DONE YOUR RESEARCH. Check out the Amazon reviews, Google and you tube, you have references at your fingertips, use them, and ask questions!! I will get off my soapbox now..... For a starter tablet I think it's the best on the market after researching all over for one with at least 512mb of ram , a 1ghz processor and a front facing camera. I purchased this so I could read books, go on you tube and check email which this tablet does with ease. Download the Amazon app store..... PROS: - Very responsive and quick, even with Resistive Screen technology. - Excellent price. - Great screen definition. - No Android market access, but the apps library has a lot of (Cheesy) apps. Additionally, you can directly install a lot Android 2.2 & 2.3 apps via the SD card. Not sanctioned, but there is a way to install Android Market. - It has USB capability, albeit difficult to locate folders at first (need to look for "tflash" folder for SD Card and "scsi_sda1", "scsi_sdb1", "scsi_sda2", etc for USB Flash Drives). - You can also access external hard drives, providing they are FAT. CONS: - Initial frequent disconnects from WI-FI. This causes the Apps Library to crash. The only way to fix it is reboot. I enabled the guest access on my Belkin and set it to WEP and still have WI-FI disconnect issues. UPDATE: The WI-FI issue has resolved itself. I even reverted back to WPA2 without any issues. Changed rating back to 5 Stars. - Micro SD card slot is finicky if you have to remove and install a micro SD card on a regular basis. - No Bluetooth. Bottom line, this is a great introductory tablet. I only wanted an ebook reader, but decided to get a little more capability. Well worth the price. It is a very good tablet for the PRICE....

Title: Excellent Laptop after a little tweaking.
Content: My primary uses for this laptop are writing software, editing PDFs, and other personal use. Overall, it is a great laptop, but needs some initial tweaking to run smoothly. Pros: Fast for its size: The 2.67Ghz core i5 is extremely fast for a laptop and 4gb of ram is plenty. Programs open quickly and PDF files are very smooth when using tablet mode. If you don't clog up the laptop with all kinds of gunkware, it will run better than you want it to. For me, using a fast touch screen is faster than using a mouse in a lot of applications. Easy to use tablet: The tablet screen is very easy to swivel and the laptop is lightweight for its speed (3.8lbs, 5lbs with extra battery) The screen and form factor are also very easy for handling and viewing. Battery expansion: The internal battery on this is rated at about 5 hours, but I get about 4hrs 20min out of it on low power mode. Note that this is after I removed a LOT of the default software that came with the computer. Using a higher power mode will probably get you 3hrs 30min on a full charge. The great thing about this laptop is the optional ultraslim battery (RX932AA). This will give you an additional 4+ hours on the system making your overall battery live 7-8 hours! Awesome for a full sized laptop! (Note that the RX932AA says its for the 2710p, but it works with the 2740p as well) Cons: HP Default Software: I removed a lot of the applications the tablet came with for several reasons. A) Not useful to me B) Free applications worked better C) Took up too much power Customizing: The default touch screen driver that comes with the laptop doesn't work well. I had to replace it with this one: "sp49201.exe" (available on the HP support site, just Google it) and now everything works perfectly. --- This is a great laptop if you need something portable with tablet functionality. After a little tweaking, it runs quickly. I would recommend this for a traveling businessman, student, or someone who really enjoys tablet functionality on a fast laptop. Though it's a little expensive, you definitely get what you pay for if you tweak it a little bit at the beginning.

Title: Great Product Esp for Amazom Prime Members
Content: Well I have been using the Kindle Fire for a week now. The price is amazing for what you get. The graphics while streaming video is simply stunning. Also I do have a high end, ($135.00), wireless router. I've read Neg. reviews here on the Kindle Fire WiFi. Trust me, the problem is in cheap wireless routers. To stream media seamlessly these days,Esp HD video, you MUST have a capable wireless router. Don't skimp there. Buy a quality dual channel router. A must have for all your WiFi devices. Also the Amazon Prime membership is the only way to fully enjoy your Kindle Fire. The TV shows and movies stream amazingly well. And so many are free for Prime Members. I mean you can't go wrong for the price plus all the free 2 day shipping or $3.99 for overnight shipping. The Amazon cloud storage is great too. And the Android app development community has the Kindle Fire slated as the number one tablet for developing apps. This is no small matter either. It means the Android App developers are betting the Kindle Fire is going to be a huge seller. My guess is it will the number one Android tablet by the second or third Kindle Fire release. I'm sure the Kindle Fire 2 will be a much better device whenever it is released, but for $199.00 tax free online for this thing, its a very good deal. I love it.

Title: Fabulous tablet, great price
Content: This is a great tablet for the price. The display is wonderful and sharp and the built quality is excellent with the nice sold aluminum casing. Having an Android phone means I'm quite familiar with the operating system, and I can say this tablet runs great! Built in speaker was adequate and the built in webcam definitely a plus for making those video call. Overall, the features of GPS, Wireless N, SD expansion and compact size makes this a wonderful deal, especially when it is price hundreds lower than the other alternative and I can browse site with flash too. Now I mainly only use the Le Pan TC970 for my daily browsing, email and game over all other devices. One item that can be improve, however, is that the power button can be a little bigger, but I can't complaint really.
